title: Past Simple: Form and Use
summary: This lesson covers the formation and usage of the past simple tense, including regular verb spelling rules and different contexts for use.
content: The past simple describes completed actions, past habits, and past situations.
Regular verbs form the past simple with -ed, while irregular verbs have unique forms.
We use past simple when we know or state when the action happened.
It's used for telling stories in chronological order and describing past routines.

rules.rule: Positive: subject + past form (regular: verb+ed / irregular: unique form)
Negative: subject + did not (didn't) + base verb
examples: We didn't go out last Saturday.

rules.rule: Verbs ending in consonant + y: change y to i + ed (study → studied)
One-syllable verbs ending in vowel+consonant: double consonant + ed (stop → stopped)
Completed actions in the past (with time references)
examples: She moved to Chester three years ago.
She washed her hair every day.
I often played in the park as a child.
When I arrived home, I took off my shoes and then relaxed.
I woke up, brushed my teeth, and had breakfast.

tips: Time expressions often used: yesterday, last week, in 2010, when I was young
For irregular verbs, you must memorize the past forms (see → saw, go → went)
In negatives and questions, use the base form after 'did'
Use past simple for completed actions, not continuous ones
For storytelling, use past simple for the main sequence of events
common_errors: Incorrect: 'Did you went to school?' Correct: 'Did you go to school?'
Incorrect: 'I didn't played football.' Correct: 'I didn't play football.'
Incorrect: 'She work here last year.' Correct: 'She worked here last year.'
